question: [File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_success()] [Metric manipulation] Can an attacker repeatedly call this function to artificially inflate PROCESSOR_SUCCESSES and LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION metrics at lines 119-122, hiding actual processing failures or creating false performance indicators? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_success()] [Version rollback] Can calling update_status_success() with an older processing_result.end_version at line 122 cause LATEST_PROCESSED_VERSION to move backwards, breaking monotonicity assumptions and causing re-processing of transactions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_success()] [Race condition] If two processors call update_status_success() concurrently for different version ranges, can race conditions in the metric updates at lines 119-122 cause incorrect version tracking? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_success()] [Database write failure] If apply_processor_status() at line 130 fails to write to the database after metrics have been updated at lines 119-122, can this cause permanent divergence between reported metrics and actual database state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_success()] [Status overwrite] Can calling this function with success=true at line 127 incorrectly overwrite error details from a previous failed attempt, losing critical debugging information? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_success()] [Integer overflow] Can processing_result.end_version at line 122 be u64::MAX, causing overflow when cast to i64 for the metric, resulting in negative or incorrect version tracking? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_success()] [Concurrent modification] If multiple threads update success status for overlapping version ranges, can the non-atomic sequence at lines 119-130 cause status inconsistencies in the database? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_err()] [Information disclosure] Does the debug logging at lines 135-139 expose sensitive error details including transaction data or internal state that could aid attackers? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_err()] [Metric manipulation] Can an attacker intentionally cause processing errors to inflate PROCESSOR_ERRORS metrics at line 140, triggering false alerts or hiding other critical issues? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_err()] [Error suppression] If apply_processor_status() at line 142 fails to write the error status to the database, is the original error lost without any notification, preventing proper error tracking? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_err()] [Race condition] Can concurrent error updates for the same version range cause database conflicts or lost error information at line 142? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: update_status_err()] [Status overwrite] If a transaction is successfully retried after an error, can stale error status from line 141-142 prevent proper recovery or confuse monitoring systems? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [SQL injection] Can malicious processor names or error details in ProcessorStatusModel be injected into the diesel query at lines 152-160, allowing SQL injection attacks? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Integer overflow] Can the get_chunks() call at line 148 overflow when calculating chunk boundaries if psms.len() is extremely large, causing incorrect chunking or missed database writes? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Chunk boundary error] Can off-by-one errors in the chunk indices at line 149 cause status records to be skipped or duplicated during database insertion? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Database deadlock] Can concurrent calls to apply_processor_status() with overlapping version ranges cause database deadlocks in the upsert operation at lines 152-160? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Partial write failure] If execute_with_better_error() fails for one chunk at lines 150-163, are earlier chunks already committed, causing partial status updates that corrupt the version tracking? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Panic on error] Does the expect() call at line 163 cause the entire indexer process to panic on any database error, even transient ones, resulting in unnecessary service interruptions? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Upsert conflict] Can the on_conflict clause at line 154 incorrectly overwrite newer status records with older ones if processing happens out of order, causing version tracking corruption? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Race condition] Can the do_update at lines 155-160 create race conditions where concurrent processors overwrite each other's status updates, losing critical error information or success markers? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Connection leak] If get_conn() at line 147 acquires a connection but execute_with_better_error() panics at line 163, can the connection leak and eventually exhaust the pool? (High)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Transaction boundary] Are all chunk writes at lines 149-164 within a single database transaction, or can partial failures leave the status table in an inconsistent state? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Memory exhaustion] If psms contains millions of status records, can the chunking and database write operations at lines 148-164 exhaust memory before completion? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Index contention] Can high-frequency upserts to the composite primary key (name, version) at line 154 cause database index lock contention, degrading overall indexer performance? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/crates/indexer/src/indexer/transaction_processor.rs] [Function: apply_processor_status()] [Timestamp manipulation] Can malicious processors manipulate the last_updated timestamp in excluded() at line 159 to make old status updates appear recent, confusing monitoring and recovery logic?
